text: Richard Nathaniel Wright (September 4, 1908 – November 28, 1960) was an American author best known for his novels that talk about the discrimination and violence experienced by many African Americans of the late 19th to mid-20th centuries. Literary critics believe his work helped change race relations in the United States in the mid-20th century.Alan Wald, "On Richard Wright's Centennial: The Great Outsider" , Solidarity. == Related pages == *List of poets from North America ==References == == Other websites == * The story of his life is retold in the radio drama "Black Boy", a presentation from Destination Freedom Category:1908 births Category:1960 deaths Category:20th-century American novelists Category:African-American people Category:American communists Category:American autobiographers Category:Burials at Père Lachaise Cemetery Category:Writers from Chicago Category:Writers from Mississippi Category:American socialists Category:American poets Category:Writers from Brooklyn Category:Deaths from coronary thrombosis
